Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Leveraging Matched Administrative Datasets to Improve Educational Practice and Long Run Life Outcomes: Toward Building a National Interdisciplinary Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal intends to develop a national community of researchers that utilizes large scale, longitudinal educational databases that are linked across the spectrum of early childhood to college, workplace and other social sets of data. The research collaborative includes an initial group of scholars in education research, education policy, anthropology, economics, psychology and social sciences from Northwestern and Duke University. These researchers are actively recruiting researchers and educational stakeholders from across the country, who are working with different educational and other data sets to improve capacity to link data together in the expanded data repositories that have been funded by the federal government.

The researchers are identifying best practices in the use of data and develop prototypes of their use. Starting from the Florida and North Carolina longitudinal data sets, the researchers are developing prototypes of how these data can be combined to answer pressing educational and social science questions that have heretofore been unable to be addressed. These prototypes are being developed collaboratively across the multiple institutions who are participating in the national community, with Northwestern and Duke serving as the conceptual hubs of the project. The prototypes inform the two national level meetings at which scholars and practitioners to share findings and stimulate the development of such research in other states.

The expansion of large scale longitudinal data in education and social sciences has resulted in a demand for new ways to link together data that has typically remained in silos across various state agencies. By developing prototypes of how these data sets should be linked, this research and development is expanding the nature of the questions that the data can inform. These questions include important policy and practice concerns that have been problematic in science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop a network of researchers and practitioners regarding the use of matched administrative datasets to improve educational practice. Our aspiration is to bring together scholars, policymakers, and practitioners from across the United States in hopes of seeding new collaborations between researchers and practitioners and improved use of research for the purposes of policymaking and policy evaluation in education. During this period, we completed four major activities: (1) We held four annual meetings of our national advisory board comprised of former governors, current state education commissioners, and other key individuals in the development and use of education data. The input was highly valuable to our overall planning. (2) We held four annual meetings of network members, which include scholars and state-level education policy leaders from 12 states. At the meetings, scholars reported research findings using state education data, and government officials described their research needs; (3) We collaborated with The Council of State Governments to apply for and receive funding from the Kauffmann Foundation to host a successful meeting of state education leaders and scholars to discuss ways to develop additional state education data systems for use by researchers; and (4) We contracted with the Russell Sage Foundation to administer a national conference on the use of administrative data in social sciences research and to publish a special issue of The Russell Sage Foundation Journal of the Social Sciences that includes papers from the conference.

 

The major objectives have been to develop a strong network of scholars and education policy leaders who collaborate to conduct research in education policy using administrative data, to nurture new relationships with additional state education policy leaders, and to enhance scholarship in education policy using administrative data.

 

Participation in the network grew to 60 members. Advisory Board meeting attendance was strong as well, with important input about the direction of the network. The application for funding to the Kaufmann Foundation was successful. The application for funding from the Russell Sage Foundation was successful, and the journal issue will be published in early 2019.

 

We have grown awareness, interest, and participation in collaborative research between scholars and education policy leaders using administrative data.

 

Graduate students attended all network member meetings, and the Russell Sage meeting. Scholars of all levels of professional development benefit from the data resources that have been developed.

 

The results are being disseminated in individual manuscripts being published by network members and the special issue of The Russell Sage Foundation Journal of the Social Sciences.

 

This project has had impact by increasing the number of scholars conducting research in education policy using administrative data, by increasing awareness of research possibilities, by increasing attentiveness of education policy leaders about the value of research using administrative data, and by publishing research using administrative data. The discipline has been changed by enhancing the practice of using administrative data to test hypotheses and evaluate programs.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2018
Modified by: Kenneth A Dodge
